What do black slavery, creationism and climate change denial all have in common? Â In the US, at least, a biblical justification and a fascinating geographic overlap. Â We look at the issues and then try to understand their historical roots, looking back to the early waves of British immigrants to the US between 1629-1775.

First, lets start with some geography. Â The map below shows the pre Civil War split between slave states, in red, and free states plus free territories, in green. The brown territories were up for contention, with a leaning towards being slave states. Â If the green territories became free states, and the brown territories were not allowed to become slave states, the number of free states would exceed the slave states, enabling anti slavery laws to be passed. This threat was the main driving force for southern secession and thus for the Civil War as the North tried to stop the South from seceding.

It is worth reminding ourselves that at this point in time the Republicans were the party of the North and the more populated areas, as the map below shows, and that Republicans were anti slavery and Democrats were generally pro slavery.
